newsitem.title: UK: India's Tata group braced for blast of competition.
newsitem.headline: India's Tata group braced for blast of competition.

text.p: India is heading into an era of unprecedented competition which will trigger a major shakeout of a number of industries, the head of the country's largest industrial group said on Thursday.
Ratan Tata, chairman of the Tata group, told BBC business programmes that India was heading for the same kind of competition as other free-market economies.
"We will have all the big names in India. We will need to compete against them," he said in an interview.

"There will not be the ideology of self-sufficiency and import substitution...there will be some pain and some bloodshed probably -- a shakeout in several industries. And we hope to be around after the shakeout."
The group has over 80 operating companies with core strengths in steel, trucks, electricity and chemicals.
Tata said increased competition posed a threat to existing market shares and Indian business would need to rethink its existing strategy.
"Undoubtably, if there are more players I doubt if we could retain our market share. And yet we should continue to be the dominant player and hopefully the best."
Tata said he favoured developing the group's own brands in overseas markets rather than forming joint ventures with foreign partners. But he acknowledged this would not be easy.
"It's an expensive proposition and a proposition that most of us have very little experience in. And it's therefore mot going to be an easy proposition to become a global player."
